fields.description:
From: Halterman, Jonathan 
Sent: Monday, May 16, 2016 10:58 PM
Subject: Re: Installation guide

I’ve taken some notes on changes we’ll probably want to make to the current install guide in order to make it more appropriate for redhat/centos 7 installs which will be the new thing in 4.3. Starting from the current 4.2.2 guide, here’s a rundown of the page changes I’ve noted so far:

Configure Bridges
  #3: Mention that actual device name will vary according to Redhat's Consistent Network Device Naming: https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Networking_Guide/ch-Consistent_Network_Device_Naming.html
  #5: Change to: systemctl restart network.service

Disable Firewall
  #1 (replaces 1a and 1b): 
  systemctl stop firewalld.service
  systemctl disable firewalld.service

Configure SELinux, 
  #1: Open /etc/selinux/config and edit the SELINUX to "enforcing" if you with to enable SELinux, else to "permissive".

Configure NTP
  Consider replacing this page with a guide on installing Chrony: https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/System_Administrators_Guide/ch-Configuring_NTP_Using_the_chrony_Suite.html

  #5: change to systemctl enable ntpd.service
  #6: change to systemctl start ntpd.service

Enable Packet Routing
  #1: Instead of refercing sysctl.conf, might be better to say /etc/sysctl.conf

Install Eucalyptus Release Packages
  #6b: New 6b step (other steps should be bumped down): systemctl start libvirtd

Start Eucalyptus
  Change all the "service foo start" instructions to "systemctl start foo.service". Ex: "service start eucalyptus-cloud" becomes "systemctl start eucalyptus-cloud.service".

Start the SC
  #2: 
  systemctl start tgtd.service
  systemctl start eucalyptus-cloud.service

——

One thing worth noting is that the big change on the Configure Bridges page for step #4 still needs a bit more confirmation, but the change will be something along the lines of what’s described above since the current instruction doesn’t work on Redhat 7. There may also be a few other changes that I’ll follow up with in the next day or so. Let me know if you have any questions about these.

Cheers,
Jonathan

comments.body: [~jhalterman] Curious about this: "Change all the "service foo start" instructions to "systemctl start foo.service"." ... is it a requirement for RHEL 7 or a preference or?

[~rusvika] have you considered NTP, as we have it documented currently, vs Chrony on RHEL7? See Jonathan's suggestion above. Asking you because I know there's at least one related security topic. Not sure if I should be asking elsewhere.

We have lots of NTP references throughout the docs:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#install-guide/configure_ntp.html general config of NTP
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#security-guide/security_task_ntp.html security related
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_elb.html with ELB
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#euca2ools-guide/euca-properties.html various properties
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#euca2ools-guide/euca-create-dhcp-options.html vpc and dhcp
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#security-guide/security_bp_networking.html related to replay detection / clock sync
[~kmeredith], the question of ntp vs chrony is better suited for 4.3.0 Red team. \CC [~tony], [~mbacchi].
[~kmeredith], RHEL changed how services are managed, from RHEL6 to RHEL7, independent of anything Euca-related. RHEL7's "systemctl" command is the equivalent of RHEL6's "service" command.
Thanks, [~lincoln.thomas] - I have used both commands on RHEL 7 and they both seemed to work so wondered. I suppose "service" is deprecated and will go soon enough.
[~kmeredith]: Correct, "service" reroutes to the "systemctl" command and is deprecated in RHEL7 so we shouldn't tell people to use it there.
Per [~gholms] EPEL is still necessary on both 6 and 7.  It's _ELRepo_ that is no longer required.
Looking at this https://access.redhat.com/sites/default/files/attachments/rhel_5_6_7_cheatsheet_27x36_1014_jcs_web.pdf ... I think there is more to do.

[~jhalterman] I believe I made all your changes; my notes -
# Configure Bridges - you mentioned needing to confirm on this and I think you did already?
# Disable Firewall - OK (related tickets)
# Configure SELinux - OK (related ticket)
# Configure NTP - awaiting Tony or Matt on Chrony
# Enable Packet Routing - OK
# Install Eucalyptus Release Packages - EPEL still valid; OK
# Start Eucalyptus - OK (should do a global search for these commands)
# Start the SC - OK (related ticket)

Question - http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#install-guide/starting_euca_console.html - does this work the same as the others? confusing because there's not an on/enable, just a start/restart (and I do not see a restart on the RH cheatsheet)

Please review and thanks!

[~kmeredith] I'm trying a complete install with this guide - will let you know if I hit any problems with starting the console. I did hit one problem earlier in the guide though:

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#install-guide/installing_euca_nightlies.html

On step 1, the URL http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/nightly/4.3 does not exist, but presumably it will soon...?

[~kmeredith], [~jhalterman], [~tony] the question above about NTP is dependent on whether or not we're ONLY telling users how to do things on EL7 or also antiquated EL6 steps.  If only EL7, then we should recommend chrony, and whether or not we provide steps or link to the redhat documentation should be discussed.  We tell users that they should do external tool/service configuration themselves for some things, and others we give them instructions.  So we could give three simple instructions to install chrony and start the chronyd service (as we do in the eucalyptus cookbook), or we could point them to the redhat docs.  I prefer the former, which would be providing the instructions which are:

1. yum install chrony
2. systemctl start chronyd
3. systemctl enable chronyd
[~mbacchi] I'm all for replacing NTP with Chrony in the docs, and agree that we should just describe config/install ourselves rather than link out.

A note from mtg with [~jhalterman] - http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/index.html#install-guide/credentials_admin_create.html page is great however the important part needs to be noted: use THESE creds after this point!
